question: https://www.quora.com/How-long-do-you-think-it-will-be-until-Earths-next-extinction-level-event-What-do-you-think-will-happen-and-do-you-think-humans-will-develop-enough-to-find-a-method-or-technology-to-survive

Answer: No.The worst case would be if we continue to react as stupidly as we are now to our various threats - climate change, growing debt, growing income inequality, global tensions, unsustainable industrial agriculture, and eventually fossil fuel exhaustion. My estimate is that if we don’t get our act together, we will see a cascading collapse around 2050. Starvation, war, and epidemics will reduce the population by about 90%. The remainder will live in conditions somewhere between the dark ages and the stone age.If we get on the stick right now we still have the ability to prevent all of this and bNo.The worst case would be if we continue to react as stupidly as we are now to our various threats - climate change, growing debt, growing income inequality, global tensions, unsustainable industrial agriculture, and eventually fossil fuel exhaustion. My estimate is that if we don’t get our act together, we will see a cascading collapse around 2050. Starvation, war, and epidemics will reduce the population by about 90%. The remainder will live in conditions somewhere between the dark ages and the stone age.If we get on the stick right now we still have the ability to prevent all of this and build a future that is better than the present. But we are running out of time.

Answer: Image by Pablo Munoz GomezIt would all depend on the extent of damage to life on Earth. The most likely event that can lead to it, would be a collision with a big object from space.Image by Pablo Munoz GomezIt would all depend on the extent of damage to life on Earth. The most likely event that can lead to it, would be a collision with a big object from space.If a new technological species emerges near to our time, it might be somewhat more difficult for them to get through some stages of industrialization because humans are depleting easily accessible resources like oil or coal. It wouldn’t set them back for too long, as this sort of issue plays out on the scale of hundreds of years and not millions. They might even find some artifacts and lost knowledge that we left behind that would give them clues on how to advance faster in some aspects. Hopefully not too fast so that they don’t destroy themselves prematurely in nuclear armageddon.The question was: If there was another extinction-level event, what are the chances of another human-like race forming? Could they be more advanced? Less advanced?

Answer: You stop existing.Your body decomposes.The people who loved you remember you for a while.Then, they, too, die, and people mostly forget about you.Your grandfather had two grandfathers. If you’re like most people, you will know very little, if anything at all, about those men. They are dead. The people who knew them are dead. That’s what will happen to you. That’s what will happen to me.Is it sad? Maybe. But I’ll be too dead to notice.

Answer: I personally use python / Django for backend development so I may seem a bit biased, but I promise This answer will be anything but that.so, basically you’re asking Django vs Nodejs.each has its strengths and weaknesses, ups and downs so stray away from the notion that one framework/technology is better than the other.both may try to solve the same problem but take different approaches, some more suitable for certain circumstances.and you as a developer will eventually choose which you may be more inclined towards.first up (so I don’t seem biased)Nodejs:Contrary to popular belief, node is a ruI personally use python / Django for backend development so I may seem a bit biased, but I promise This answer will be anything but that.so, basically you’re asking Django vs Nodejs.each has its strengths and weaknesses, ups and downs so stray away from the notion that one framework/technology is better than the other.both may try to solve the same problem but take different approaches, some more suitable for certain circumstances.and you as a developer will eventually choose which you may be more inclined towards.first up (so I don’t seem biased)Nodejs:Contrary to popular belief, node is a runtime environment and not an actual framework.what that means is that basically it allows JavaScript to run outside just a browser.Express is the framework used in Nodejs for backend development.here’s the deal.Amongst other things, Nodejs is known for its flexibility.It gives you the option of starting from scratch and building your entire backend from there.This is great if you want everything custom built.Also with little to no bloatware as I’d call it, Nodejs is very fast when it comes to the implementation of features.Django :On the other hand is known to come loaded with everything you need really. It comes packed with a bunch ready to implement solutions , which basically means it solves most of the common problems you’d encounter in building a backend in house. It comes with a tonnn of features out the box and there’s probably no backend related problem django doesn’t have a solution to.what does this mean for a developer?time of development reduces drastically.although, this means you give up flexibility and end up following The strict structure Which Django provides And ultimately this means you have less room to mess up.ofcourse there are lots of other advantages and disadvantages of both frameworks but I feel these are the most potent in deciding which to go with.at the end of the day it’s your choice as a developer to make the decision as to what tool would be most suitable for a job, so don’t see one as better than the other, rather see all as tools to solve problems.I personally would advise to go with django ;)

Answer: You are not a .NET developer.Let’s consider construction:Foreman: “Bart, screw in these screws.”F: “Why not?”F: “You mean you’ve only ever hammered in things?”F: “Well we screw in a lot of things too. You’ll need to learn to use a screwdriver.”F: “That’s okay. You can learn. Let me show you.”F: “It’s okay. You’ll get used to it.”Eventually, Bart was an expert screwer. But theyYou are not a .NET developer.Let’s consider construction:Foreman: “Bart, screw in these screws.”F: “Why not?”F: “You mean you’ve only ever hammered in things?”F: “Well we screw in a lot of things too. You’ll need to learn to use a screwdriver.”F: “That’s okay. You can learn. Let me show you.”F: “It’s okay. You’ll get used to it.”Eventually, Bart was an expert screwer. But they didn’t call him a “screwer” or a “hammerer”. He was simply a construction worker and knew how to use a variety of different tools.Just because you’ve only used .NET languages for the past three years doesn’t mean you’ll have to start all over from square one. You still know all the methodologies and fundamental software engineering principles. You’ll just apply them in a different language (or languages).I learned Pascal, C, C++ and Assembly in college. I used C++ exclusively for the first few years of my career. Then I learned Java. Then HTML and CSS (not programming languages, but technologies). Then C#. Then JavaScript. Then SQL. Then Python.Learning Pascal was the hardest. The others came easier because they were all just languages. Syntax is different, but the outcome is the same: working programs.Learn some of Golang and/or Python before applying for jobs that require it, but know that as a software engineer, you’ve already completed half the battle.Good luck!

Answer: April 2013,I deployed a new feature to production on day 4 of my first ever job in the industry. I didn’t fully understand how the testing and deployment automation worked and was just excited to get my first code checkin out. Naturally I broke things; I ended up taking down my entire service across Europe. An experienced team member who was OnCall at the time got paged when he was in a meeting and he came out and walked over to my desk and explained what had happened. He showed me how to roll back the checkin to mitigate the damage for the time beingApril 2013,I deployed a new feature to production on day 4 of my first ever job in the industry. I didn’t fully understand how the testing and deployment automation worked and was just excited to get my first code checkin out. Naturally I broke things; I ended up taking down my entire service across Europe. An experienced team member who was OnCall at the time got paged when he was in a meeting and he came out and walked over to my desk and explained what had happened. He showed me how to roll back the checkin to mitigate the damage for the time being. He then sat me down and explained all the things that had gone wrong, why they didn’t work despite the code review and how I should test code before deploying. My manager came by later that day and sat with me and showed me some additional tips and tricks to optimize the process.Do you know what my key takeaway was from that first week; from that seemingly harrowing experience to a new college grad?Over my three years at Amazon, I have broken multiple systems multiple times and watched so many others do the same. The more severe ones that resulted in outages for our customers required that we do a detailed post-mortem and write a doc about it. The rigor was put in place for the team to get better. Nobody was ever punished for making a mistake; it was always used asLEARN and GROWAmazon gets a lot of bad press about the hectic schedules, the lack of work life balance, the OnCall schedules, etc. Somehow I never understood why any of these are issues. You know what you’re signing up for when you walk out of that interview room. Nobody promised you rainbows and unicorns;In my three years at Amazon, there were exactly two days when I felt genuinely burnt out and thought that maybe this was a bad idea.“Work Hard, Have Fun, Make History.” - Jeff B.One of the first hikes with colleagues who in due course would turn into the best of friends; the 2am phone calls among strangers in a strange land.Edit:In case we haven’t met before, I’m

Answer: It really depends: if you want a cool name on your resume - we all do some stage in our career - go with a large corporation. You have to do It at dome stage, otherwise you’ll be wondering your whole life whether you were “good enough” to work at a well-known company. Just don’t expect to make a difference there: Large companies are often slow, risk-averse, and will cancel many projects they embark on. In addition, in a large company your job is to be a cog in the machinery.If you want to make a difference go for a small company. Everyone’s contribution is naturally more important there becausIt really depends: if you want a cool name on your resume - we all do some stage in our career - go with a large corporation. You have to do It at dome stage, otherwise you’ll be wondering your whole life whether you were “good enough” to work at a well-known company. Just don’t expect to make a difference there: Large companies are often slow, risk-averse, and will cancel many projects they embark on. In addition, in a large company your job is to be a cog in the machinery.If you want to make a difference go for a small company. Everyone’s contribution is naturally more important there because there are less people. Small companies often appreciate people with passion that want to make a difference.
name: Hector Quintanilla
question: https://www.quora.com/How-long-do-you-think-it-will-be-until-Earths-next-extinction-level-event-What-do-you-think-will-happen-and-do-you-think-humans-will-develop-enough-to-find-a-method-or-technology-to-survive

Answer: In order to develop a warp drive, we first have to discover some things about the laws of physics that we don’t currently know.There’s no currently existing technology that we could point at and say, “If we keep on developing this, it will eventually lead to a warp drive.” Nothing that we have suggests that possibility.What will happen in the distant future can’t be rationally predicted, not even in terms of likelihood. We don’t know the first damn thing about it. It can only be fantasized about …and worried about. It’s possible that we humans won’t be around any more in the distant future. ThIn order to develop a warp drive, we first have to discover some things about the laws of physics that we don’t currently know.There’s no currently existing technology that we could point at and say, “If we keep on developing this, it will eventually lead to a warp drive.” Nothing that we have suggests that possibility.What will happen in the distant future can’t be rationally predicted, not even in terms of likelihood. We don’t know the first damn thing about it. It can only be fantasized about …and worried about. It’s possible that we humans won’t be around any more in the distant future. There are actually some plausible indicators to base that one on.
